sentences.text: hey, what's going on Alex?
Hello.
How are you?
I'm good.
How are you?
I'm great.
Nice.
Where are you calling out of today?
I am in Madison Georgia.
Oh, very cool.
How about you?
I'm based out of Brooklyn New York.
Oh, wow.
Okay.
But I appreciate, you know, the both of you hopping on the call here today.
So just to hop into it and set a quick agenda, we'd love to do a quick round of introductions, understand both your roles, what got you interested in hiver.
Then we can jump into a product demonstration, and then we'll just save some time at the end for any questions and next steps, but I can kick us off first on the introductions.
So, my name is Cole miller.
I'm a senior account executive here at hiver.
I've been in the email management, customer experience space for a little over six years now, and yeah, just looking forward to seeing how we can potentially help you all today.
By the way?
I do, I'm having trouble technologically I can't see anything.
I'm not sure what's going on.
It's interesting.
All I can see is me.
So anyway, I'm chip Morris, I'm the founder and CEO of procivica and I will get this fixed.
I don't mind looking at myself, but I'd rather see you guys.
Well, we don't have cameras on if that makes you feel any better, no.
Okay.
Fair enough.
But I'm going to have to say, I think that you're going to have to share some stuff aren't you?
Yeah.
Okay.
All right.
Let's go.
We're good, Alex, introduce yourself?
Yeah, Alex, Lundy, director of operations for procivica.
And I've been with the company now for I think actually four years.
I told somebody three the other day.
I think it's four years now.
Right at it.
Okay.
Yeah.
Well, great to meet you both.
So just to kind of understand further, you know, chip it out.
So like what brought you here to hiver today?
Like what are you looking to solve for?
Yep.
Well, I'll jump in and then I'll let Alex add to it.
Our company is procivica and you can see us at procivica com.
We're currently using a product called talkto.
We did that because it was just, you know, we were building our new website and building our new platform.
And somebody said just we need something to go ahead and go with these guys.
It looks like it because a good thing to start with is cheap or whatever.
I don't even remember what pushed us in that direction but we did it because we needed to do something and it's working okay, but it's a lot of moving parts.
And basically, this is what we need.
We have people who are ordered to take classes first and second offenders, whether they're young adults or juveniles as well.
As we have probation officers and folks who go in there to register folks.
Those are the people who land on our site and who need help.
70 percent to 80 percent of the questions probably could be answered via AI via the chat bot, AI chat bot.
We want a simple system to be able to track that, but know that just not even worry about that.
We know that it's trained, right?
We know it's given the right answers, it's not giving weird answers to the folks.
It's resolving their issues.
And when it's not a very simple way for them to escalate that.
And we don't have a live person sitting there waiting.
So it would need to be a ticket that triggers us.
It says, hey, somebody's here.
They need help.
And then we can clearly see it and we can track those things.
What are those things that are causing people to need help, personal attention, one on one.
And so we want that's it, we want it to be clean.
Now, I've landed on hiver, you asked the question.
We chat gpt, we went in there.
I searched, I said what are the top ones that would fit our needs?
And it gave a few others.
One of them was one of your competitors and it just didn't work out.
Man.
I looked at them and it was helpscout right?
There were a lot of weird pricing issues around what they have, good product for the most part from what I could tell, but I didn't want to go any further because this is too weird.
The pricing structure is bizarre and we do lean heavily on AI chatbot and their pricing was weird.
So that's where we are that's what we need.
And we'd love to hear what you guys can do for us.

So you're primarily just looking for an AI chatbot like for the website that's like the number one use case, something that can, you know, deflect conversations, run into end to end conversation without, you know, other folks getting involved.
Correct, and then obviously escalate to a ticket.
So we can then we can track that.
So those two things Alex, please jump in.
What are your thoughts?
Because I want Alex's hands on in this daily discussion.
Yeah, I think that's a really good summary.
The only thing I would add is the nuance to our customer base.
We have several very distinct populations of users.
And so differentiating those answers to the appropriate type of user has been difficult for us.
One thing that talkto can do that we'd like to try to keep the functionality.
I guess if we move services would be distinguishing what kind of user the customer is and being able to answer appropriately.
For example, we have adult learners and juvenile learners.
Juvenile learners do not pay for their courses.
So there's no, how much does this cost?
How do I pay?
What forms of payment?
Do you take all those types of questions?
You know, it would need to answer appropriately to adults versus juveniles?
And we also work with the learners themselves and with court staff.
So the questions there are very different for those populations.
And the way that we've handled that so far has been just a simple form fill off the bat.
Are you a learner or a court staff?
Are you an adult or a juvenile?
And then being able to tailor the answers accordingly?
Yeah, you can see.
It, right?
You can see that form if you go there.
Right.

And are you currently using more conditional logic where if they select a button, it takes them down that conditional logic path or is it like actually conversational AI that's searching through your internal sources?
I think my hunch is that one of the issues that we're having is we're doing both of those things.
It's supposed to reference their answer on the form and then answer accordingly, right?
So if they've clicked the radio button for juvenile, it should be answering them as a juvenile.
But we… also have built several, they call them like triggers.
It's a very complex process creating the… conversational triggers.
We've uploaded a document and we know we can put in text and we've got our faqs and they can, you know, they scrub our website, but then we upload a CSV to Scott.
Here are the questions, but here are the answers to these three populations and you've got juvenile adult and then probation officer.
And so it's supposed to answer it based upon when they answer that.
Then it's going to only go to that pile of answers, right?
And I think that for the most part works really well.
It's the more complex stuff that has been built in the system.
As far as those trigger paths that you're talking about, we have tried to do some of that but it's so complicated.
We just really haven't been able to nail it.
And I think the both of those methods working against each other is causing some of the issues that we're seeing.
Okay.
I got it.
And are you doing any email management today or is this strictly for chat?
It's strictly for chat.
And when you say email, you mean like email support, people emailing us for support?
Yeah, exactly.

We handle that without any issues now as we scale just to let you know where we're positioned right now, we just invested a lot in our company to be able to go national to be able to be anywhere and then hold the weight of that.
That's another reason we've got to get this right?
Because as we scale, so do our problems and customer service issues.
So or not our problems, but challenges and customer service issues increase, we want to be prepared for that.
So I do anticipate we eventually will want to be able to deal with some email, incoming email support.
But right now we can handle that.
It's mainly we want to deal with it when they land on our site and they're taking care of it and they need help, right?
Yeah.
Okay.
No, that's perfect.
So I can just show you what we have right now for chat.
So right now we have more conditional logic but being released in a couple weeks, we have a very powerful generative AI platform chat agent that's going to be released.
So I think as a, you know, once that's released, we can serve that as like a follow up to show you that workflow.
But right now I'll just show you what we have currently.
So what's nice about hiver team and kind of how we differentiate, right?
We live within the Google workspace, and are you using Gmail or outlook today before I go further?
We use Gmail workspace.
Okay.
You're using Google workspace.
Got it.
So, you know, you'll have access to hiver by logging into your Gmail environment.
And then this is the backend, right?

The admin panel where we're setting up our channels whether it's email management, chat, whatsapp, voice, knowledge base, customer portal, or also those automations and integrations that we might have.
So this is kind of where we'll set it all up but going to, you know, the knowledge base.

So this is what you can host on the website, have articles to hopefully self serve people before they even reach out to have, you know, a conversation for your team.
But let's say, you know, we're going to start a new conversation here.
Okay.
So now I'm engaging you know, with chat and we can prompt that conversation, right?

So I'll select user addition, and it's going to prompt another question, right?
Do I want to invite a user to account, share mailbox?

And I can keep clicking these buttons as it takes me down that guided workflow from either where this is going to be able to self serve and deflect the ticket away from your team and just help them themselves or to a point where we need to escalate it and bring it to someone from a live chat experience with more of a human touch.
So, and then going to the, you know, Google side.
So this is the sales chat folder on the left hand side that will live in the workspace.
And I can click in and see what's assigned to the bot right now.
And this is actually the conversation that I'm having.

really like that.
